study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of fluoride mouthwash on the surface micro-hardness of two types of CAD/CAM ceramics after exposure to acidic solutions.
results_summary: The study found that fluoride mouthwash, when used with acidic solutions, adversely affected the microhardness of both Vitabloc Mark II CAD and IPS e.max CAD ceramics, with Vitabloc Mark II CAD being significantly more affected.
population_specificity: CAD/CAM ceramic samples (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical efficacy and safety of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash in dentistry, focusing on its optimal protocols and adverse effects.
results_summary: CHX mouthwash was found to be superior for short-term use in preventing gingivitis and maintaining oral hygiene when mechanical prophylaxis was not possible, with tooth staining being the most common adverse effect. Concentrations of 0.12% to 0.2% were recommended, as higher concentrations increased side effects without added benefits.
population_specificity: Patients in dentistry, including those undergoing oral surgery, periodontics, and general dental care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate and zinc chloride mouthwashes in reducing oral mucositis and improving quality of life in chemotherapy patients.
results_summary: Both sodium bicarbonate and zinc chloride mouthwashes significantly reduced the severity of oral mucositis and improved quality of life compared to placebo, with effects evident by the first week and sustained through the third week.
population_specificity: 144 cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of herbal mouthwashes in preventing radiation-induced mucositis (RIOM) in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: Both herbal mouthwashes were similarly effective in reducing the severity of RIOM, with average mucositis scores below 2 for all groups. They slightly delayed the onset of RIOM, though not statistically significant, and patients showed no clear preference among the mouthwashes.
population_specificity: 120 patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy.
study_duration: Throughout the radiotherapy course (6 weeks) plus one-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral effects of antiseptic mouthrinses, particularly benzalkoniumchloride (BAC), against SARS-CoV-2 in vitro and in a clinical trial to assess potential reduction of viral loads in the oral cavity.
results_summary: In vitro, BAC and other antiseptic agents effectively inactivated SARS-CoV-2 by disrupting the viral envelope, but clinical application resulted in only a mild reduction of viral loads in the oral cavity, suggesting limited impact on transmission rates.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of a polyphenol-rich mouthwash/gel/gingival paste as an adjuvant therapy for oral diseases in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that polyphenols and other natural bioactive compounds (NBCs) could modulate oral microbiota, prevent dysbiosis, and exert anti-inflammatory effects, potentially benefiting CKD patients with oral diseases. However, no specific clinical results or efficacy data are provided.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients with oral diseases such as periodontitis, bone lesions, infections, or oral cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of henna and chlorhexidine mouthwashes as adjunctive therapy for oral lichen planus (OLP) when used alongside topical corticosteroids.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief or clinical improvement between henna and chlorhexidine mouthwashes when used with corticosteroids. Both treatments provided symptom relief, but further research is needed to confirm henna mouthwash's efficacy as a standalone or adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: Forty patients with oral lichen planus (OLP), 82.6% of whom were women.
effective_dosage: Henna mouthwash (2% aqueous extract of henna, 2% ethanol, 10% glycerol, and 0.1% methylparaben in distilled water) used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the post-operative anti-inflammatory efficacy of chlorhexidine (CHX), 2% saline rinses (SR), and a herbal mouthwash (MW) after non-surgical mechanical debridement for treating peri-implant mucositis (PiM).
results_summary: At 12 weeks, all three mouthwash groups (CHX, saline, and herbal) showed statistically significant reductions in peri-implant inflammation and probing depth compared to baseline, with no significant differences between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with peri-implant mucositis.
effective_dosage: 0.12% non-alcoholic CHX, 2% NaCl rinses, and herbal-based MW (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-inflammatory efficacy of 2% saline rinses and a herbal mouthwash versus chlorhexidine in patients with periodontal inflammation, particularly those with chlorhexidine allergy.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvements in plaque index, gingival index, and probing depth after 6 weeks, with no significant difference in clinical attachment loss. Herbal mouthwash and saline rinses were found suitable for patients with chlorhexidine allergy.
population_specificity: Young adults with periodontal inflammation, including those with self-reported chlorhexidine allergy.
effective_dosage: 2% saline rinses and herbal mouthwash (specific frequency not mentioned); 0.12% chlorhexidine for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of propolis in maintaining oral health, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and other beneficial properties.
results_summary: Propolis significantly reduced plaque and gingival indices, inhibited bacterial growth, reduced oral flora diversity, and improved periodontal condition, oral hygiene, and oral health across 19 studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general oral health focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of 12 weeks of daily mouthwash use on the oropharyngeal microbiota and compare the efficacy of two alcohol-free mouthwashes (Listerine and Biotène) for preventing gonorrhea transmission.
results_summary: The study analyzed changes in oropharyngeal microbiota composition after 12 weeks of daily mouthwash use, employing 16S rRNA gene sequencing and statistical methods (PERMANOVA, ALDEx2). No specific efficacy outcomes for gonorrhea prevention were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM) participating in a randomized trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial effects and safety profiles of chlorhexidine-based mouthwashes with those containing chlorine dioxide and/or polyhexanide for controlling oral microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwashes containing chlorine dioxide and polyhexanide are viable alternatives to chlorhexidine, effectively reducing oral biofilm with little or no reported side effects. Four studies reported no adverse effects, while one study noted side effects, and three did not address safety outcomes.
population_specificity: 295 young adults, adults, and elderly individuals (44.75% male, 55.25% female).
effective_dosage: Concentrations varied across studies (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fluoride-free oral care products containing hydroxyapatite (HAP) effectively reduce dental caries compared to fluoride-containing or no caries control products.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 3 RCTs showed HAP provided 17% protection against caries, with some trials indicating non-inferior performance compared to fluoride products. The systematic review included 22 studies, with simpler proxy outcomes in 17 trials supporting HAP's anticaries effects.
population_specificity: Individuals of all ages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of herbal and chlorhexidine-based mouthwashes for oral hygiene maintenance in patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with one RCT favoring chlorhexidine, another favoring herbal mouthwashes, and three showing comparable effects. Chlorhexidine demonstrated higher antimicrobial efficacy against S. mutans in two studies, while one found comparable efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of different decontamination methods, including chlorhexidine mouthwash (CHX), for reducing Staphylococcus aureus on SLA surface mini-implants.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash (CHX) showed the second-highest efficacy in reducing bacterial contamination, outperformed only by the combined use of titanium brush and citric acid. The study found significant differences in colony counts between treatment groups, with CHX demonstrating strong decontamination effects.
population_specificity: Mini-implants contaminated with Staphylococcus aureus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash on dental implants with peri-implant mucositis and contralateral teeth with gingivitis after nonsurgical treatment.
results_summary: The study found that 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash reduced bleeding on probing in implant sites compared to teeth sites at 6 months, indicating reduced inflammation. However, no differences were observed between groups at the patient level, and implant sites with thin peri-implant phenotypes or posterior locations showed greater inflammation.
population_specificity: 30 patients diagnosed with peri-implant mucositis and gingivitis in contralateral teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a probiotic mouth rinse (containing Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Bifidobacterium longum, and Saccharomyces boulardii) as an adjunct to mechanical debridement in managing stage II periodontitis, and to assess changes in salivary pH and IgA levels.
results_summary: The probiotic mouth rinse significantly improved periodontal parameters (gingival index, probing depth, clinical attachment gain) compared to placebo, and elevated salivary IgA and pH levels. Both groups showed improvement, but the probiotic group demonstrated superior outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 patients with stage II periodontitis, randomized into probiotic and placebo groups (n=30 each).
effective_dosage: Mouth rinse used twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash on reducing the salivary load of SARS-CoV-2.
results_summary: The study found that 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate significantly reduced SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva at 5 and 60 minutes post-use compared to placebo, with 72% of the test group showing reduced viral load versus 30% in the control group.
population_specificity: 100 participants positive for SARS-CoV-2.
effective_dosage: 15 ml of 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate, single use.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured at 5 and 60 minutes post-use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an herbal licorice mouthwash compared to chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing salivary bacteria in high caries risk patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between licorice and chlorhexidine mouthwashes in reducing salivary bacteria in high caries risk patients. Licorice mouthwash showed promising antibacterial effects, suggesting it could be a suitable alternative to synthetic mouthwashes.
population_specificity: High caries risk patients (n=52)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Pudilan Keyanning antibacterial mouthwash, chlorhexidine acetate mouthwash (0.12%), and a placebo in controlling plaque and improving periodontal health during the maintenance phase of periodontitis treatment.
results_summary: The study measured clinical parameters (plaque index, bleeding index), volatile sulfide levels in breath, and microbiological analysis of subgingival plaque, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. Questionnaire feedback was also analyzed, though outcomes were not specified.
population_specificity: 120 participants in the periodontal maintenance phase.
effective_dosage: Rinsed with mouthwash two times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a photocatalytic device (Germinator) and its combination with hydrogen peroxide (HP) or chlorhexidine (CHX) for bacterial decontamination in the oral cavity.
results_summary: The highest bacterial reduction was observed with 3.0% HP, 1.5% HP + Germinator, and 3.0% HP + Germinator, with no significant difference between them. Germinator alone showed higher bacterial reduction than the control and 0.12% CHX.
population_specificity: 64 subjects aged 18-65, randomly assigned to eight groups.
effective_dosage: 1.5% HP, 3.0% HP, 0.12% CHX, and Germinator (protocol not detailed).

study_goal: To determine whether rhinopharyngeal irrigation and mouth-gurgling with dissolved mupirocin is a feasible and potentially efficacious supplementary strategy against treatment-resistant MRSA throat carriage.
results_summary: 90% of patients complied with the treatment protocol with no major adverse events. At one and six months post-treatment, 83% and 39% of patients, respectively, had negative MRSA sampling results.
population_specificity: 20 treatment-resistant MRSA throat carriers.
effective_dosage: 22 g 2% mupirocin ointment per litre of isotonic sterile saline solution, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of essential oil-based mouthwashes in controlling gingivitis in patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: Four studies indicated that Listerine (an EO-based mouthwash) was effective in controlling gingivitis, as measured by clinical indices. The review included six clinical studies, with risk of bias assessed using standardized tools.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) on dental care during the COVID-19 pandemic, including the recommendation of mouthwash to minimize SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
results_summary: The study found that most CPGs recommended mouthwash prior to dental care as part of measures to reduce COVID-19 transmission risk, alongside other infection control practices like rubber dam use and high-volume evacuators.
population_specificity: Dental staff and patients receiving dental care during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a hypochlorite-based mouthwash versus chlorhexidine mouthwash in resolving peri-implant mucositis when paired with non-surgical periodontal therapy.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant clinical improvements, but the hypochlorite-based mouthwash (test group) demonstrated greater efficacy than chlorhexidine (control group) at the seventh-day evaluation. The study concluded that the hypochlorite-based formula could be a viable alternative to chlorhexidine for peri-implant mucositis.
population_specificity: Patients in a periodontal maintenance program diagnosed with peri-implant mucositis.
study_duration: 10 days of domestic use followed by a 90-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity and cytotoxicity of an anionic phthalocyanine derivative (APD) in mouthwash and its clinical effects on hospitalized COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that APD mouthwash significantly reduced SARS-CoV-2 viral load in vitro (92.65%-99.96%) and shortened hospital stays (4 vs. 7 days) while reducing ICU admissions and mortality in the experimental group.
population_specificity: Hospitalized COVID-19 patients (non-intensive care)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of antibacterial mouthwash as a novel prevention strategy for bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that antibacterial mouthwash is being investigated as a potential prevention strategy for bacterial STIs, but no specific efficacy results or outcomes related to mouthwash are detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general STI prevention context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical efficacy of a propolis-containing mouthwash in treating gingivitis compared to a placebo mouthwash.
results_summary: The propolis mouthwash significantly reduced gingival inflammation and bleeding compared to the placebo, with no significant difference in plaque reduction. It also did not cause tooth discoloration, unlike the placebo.
population_specificity: 32 patients with gingivitis (16 in the intervention group, 16 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial effect of a green tea infusion used as a mouthwash compared to distilled water.
results_summary: The study found that green tea mouthwash significantly reduced colony-forming units in saliva and bacterial plaque compared to the placebo (distilled water), demonstrating an antibacterial effect.
population_specificity: 28 students aged 18-40 years.
effective_dosage: 10 mL of a 13% green tea infusion (13 g green tea in 100 mL saline solution), used once for rinsing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as mouthwash and nasal spray for symptom relief in COVID-19 patients and its potential to prevent infection in their family members.
results_summary: H2O2 was not effective for relieving COVID-19 symptoms and was associated with transient adverse effects like burning throat and nose. Among family members, there was no significant difference in infection rates between the experimental and control groups.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (hospitalized or at home) and their family members (SARS-CoV-2 negative).
effective_dosage: 1% H2O2 for gargling (3 times/day), 0.5% H2O2 for nasal wash (2 times/day).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of a flavored, non-fluoridated, alcohol-free mouthwash containing 0.1% chlorine dioxide in reducing oral malodor.
results_summary: The mouthwash significantly reduced oral malodor during the first 3 weeks of use (Phase I) and showed efficacy again in the last two weeks after crossover (Phase II). No adverse effects were reported, indicating safety for up to 3 weeks of use.
population_specificity: Fifty subjects with clinically diagnosed intrinsic oral malodor.
effective_dosage: Twice-daily use of 0.1% chlorine dioxide mouthwash.
study_duration: 8 weeks (with a 2-week washout period between phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of curcumin as an adjuvant to oral hygiene on plaque index, gingival index, gingival bleeding index, and inflammation in patients with gingivitis, comparing it to chlorhexidine mouthwash.
results_summary: Curcumin treatment significantly reduced plaque index, gingival index, gingival bleeding index, and microbial colony count, demonstrating comparable efficacy to chlorhexidine mouthwash with no serious adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zinc chloride mouthwash on preventing and reducing the incidence and severity of oral mucositis in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Zinc chloride mouthwash significantly reduced the incidence and severity of oral mucositis compared to placebo, particularly by the second and third weeks. It also significantly improved weight retention in patients.
population_specificity: 96 cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy from an oncology clinic in western Iran.
effective_dosage: 7.5 ml rinsed every 8 hours, twice daily for 2 minutes each time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of three mouthwashes (benzydamine, sodium bicarbonate, and glutamine) for alleviating oral complications in colon cancer patients receiving 5-FU-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: Glutamine mouthwash was significantly more effective than benzydamine and sodium bicarbonate in reducing oral complications (dryness, mucositis, pain) and showed slight improvements in psychological discomfort and quality of life.
population_specificity: 90 colon cancer patients receiving 5-FU-based chemotherapy in Istanbul, Turkey.
effective_dosage: Group A: benzydamine 15 mL; Group B: sodium bicarbonate 1.2-2.4 g in 240 mL water; Group C: glutamine suspension 10 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether twice-daily gargling with chlorhexidine 0.2% could eradicate Neisseria gonorrhoeae from the oropharynx of asymptomatic men who have sex with men.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash (chlorhexidine 0.2%) was completely ineffective (0% efficacy) in eradicating Neisseria gonorrhoeae in the tested population. The trial was ended early due to lack of efficacy.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic men who have sex with men (n = 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an anti-inflammatory mouthwash versus tacrolimus ointment in reducing symptoms and signs of oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The mouthwash was effective in reducing OLP signs and symptoms, but tacrolimus showed significantly better improvement at the 3-month follow-up. Both treatments demonstrated significant control of OLP.
population_specificity: 38 patients with oral lichen planus (OLP) diagnosed by clinical and histopathological criteria.
effective_dosage: Mouthwash composition: calcium hydroxide 10%, hyaluronic acid 0.3%, umbelliferone, and oligomeric proanthocyanidins (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ginger and aloe vera mouthwashes on xerostomia in diabetic patients.
results_summary: Both ginger and aloe vera mouthwashes significantly reduced xerostomia symptoms and severity, with ginger showing a greater reduction (6.12 cm) compared to aloe vera (4.08 cm) and normal saline (2.45 cm).
population_specificity: Diabetic patients referred to Bandar Abbas diabetes clinic in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the staining effects of chlorhexidine mouthwash versus a diluted chlorhexidine-based mouth rinse (Orthokin) in fixed orthodontic patients.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash significantly increased tooth staining (stain extent and overall stain indices) after 8 weeks, while Orthokin mouthwash did not cause significant discoloration. Both mouthwashes maintained oral hygiene effectiveness.
population_specificity: 50 fixed orthodontic patients aged 14-30 years.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of green tea mouthwash for improving oral health status in oral cancer patients undergoing cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that green tea mouthwash significantly improved oral health status compared to tap water, with notable improvements observed at 4 months and sustained up to 6 months. The intervention group showed a significant decrease in oral health status scores, indicating better outcomes.
population_specificity: Oral cancer patients (>20 years old) undergoing cancer treatment, excluding those with mental illness, severe acute illness, complete edentulism, or inability to open the mouth more than 1 cm.
effective_dosage: 100 ml of green tea solution, used for 60 seconds after each teeth-brushing procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an intervention bundle, including peppermint water mouthwash, could effectively relieve thirst and dry mouth in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed a significantly greater reduction in thirst intensity and oral mucosa scores compared to the control group, indicating the intervention bundle, including mouthwash, was effective. Being male, higher Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II scores, absence of diuretics, and elevated serum sodium levels were linked to thirst and oral dryness.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients (average age 64.2 ± 16.8 years, 65.6% male).
effective_dosage: Peppermint water mouthwash (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of an oleanolic acid-containing toothpaste compared to a fluoride toothpaste and chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing gingival inflammation and plaque in patients with gingivitis.
results_summary: The chlorhexidine mouthwash group showed significantly greater reductions in gingival and plaque indices compared to the negative control and oleanolic acid groups, though adverse events were similar across groups. Oleanolic acid toothpaste did not outperform fluoride toothpaste in antiplaque or antigingivitis effects after two weeks.
population_specificity: 99 patients with gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 10% tranexamic acid (TXA) mouthwash reduces post-extraction bleeding in patients on non-vitamin K oral anticoagulants (NOACs).
results_summary: TXA mouthwash did not significantly reduce periprocedural or early postoperative bleeding compared to placebo but showed a reduction in delayed bleeding and bleeding after multiple extractions. No significant safety concerns were reported, with only one thrombotic event in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients on NOACs undergoing dental extraction (mean age ~74 years, predominantly male).
effective_dosage: 10% TXA mouthwash, used once prior to extraction and then 3 times daily for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of oral products, including chlorhexidine and herbal medications, in preventing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in tracheally intubated patients.
results_summary: The study found that chlorhexidine and some herbal medications effectively reduce VAP by decreasing microbial flora in the mouth, with herbal options presenting comparable benefits to chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing tracheal intubation in intensive care units (ICUs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) mouthwash and nasal spray as an auxiliary treatment for COVID-19 in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in symptom severity or hospital stay length between the H2O2 and control groups, though most experimental group patients reported reduced dyspnea early. H2O2 was deemed safe with few adverse effects but lacked evidence for efficacy in COVID-19 treatment.
population_specificity: Hospitalized COVID-19 patients (n=40) confirmed via RT-PCR.
effective_dosage: 1.0% H2O2 mouthwash and 0.5% H2O2 nasal wash.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the caries preventive and antibacterial effects of Gum Arabic and Licorice mouthwashes versus chlorhexidine in high caries-risk patients and assess oral side effects.
results_summary: No significant differences in DMF scores were found between the groups at baseline, 3, 6, and 9 months, but after 12 months, chlorhexidine (G3) showed significantly higher DMF scores compared to Gum Arabic (G1) and Licorice (G2). Gum Arabic and Licorice mouthwashes demonstrated promising caries preventive and antibacterial effects with no reported oral side effects.
population_specificity: High caries-risk patients (63 participants) categorized by the CAMBRA caries-risk model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mouthwash containing 1% metronidazole as a local drug delivery system, combined with scaling and root planning, in treating periodontal infections.
results_summary: The study found that mouthwash significantly reduced clinical parameters and inflammatory biomarkers (TNF-α, PGE2, nitric oxide) compared to conventional treatment, though it was less effective than the gel formulation in reducing clinical attachment loss and inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of curcumin mouthwashes in reducing dental plaque and gingivitis compared to chlorhexidine.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that curcumin mouthwashes had comparable efficacy to chlorhexidine in reducing plaque and gingivitis, though most studies had a high risk of bias. Further trials with standardized methods are needed for conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: 320 subjects across six randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a 40% miswak mouthwash versus a 0.12% chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing gingival, bleeding, and plaque indices.
results_summary: The study found that miswak mouthwash was less effective than chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing gingival, bleeding, and plaque indices, though it was still considered a good oral hygiene agent for long-term use.
population_specificity: 60 patients aged 20-55 years attending Periodontics Clinics at Al-Iraqia University, Baghdad, Iraq.
effective_dosage: 40% miswak mouthwash or 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of sodium hypochlorite mouthwash (NaOCl-MW) with a control mouthwash on plaque and clinical parameters of periodontal disease.
results_summary: NaOCl-MW showed a very small beneficial effect on plaque index (PI), gingival index (GI), and bleeding index (BI) compared to a negative control, but no significant effect on probing pocket depth (PPD). Compared to chlorhexidine mouthwash (CHX-MW), NaOCl-MW had similar effects on GI and BI, with one study favoring NaOCl-MW for PI.
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis or periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of propolis mouth rinse (hot and cold ethanolic extracts) with Chlorhexidine mouthwash in reducing oral pathogens, plaque, and gingival index scores.
results_summary: Propolis mouth rinse was as effective as Chlorhexidine in reducing S. mutans and L. acidophilus counts, plaque, and gingivitis. Both hot and cold ethanolic propolis extracts showed significant antimicrobial activity.
population_specificity: 120 participants in a randomized controlled trial.
effective_dosage: Twice daily rinsing (specific volume not stated).

study_goal: To evaluate the antibacterial effects and compatibility of a CPC/GK2/TXA mouthwash after implant placement surgery.
results_summary: The mouthwash significantly reduced bacterial colony-forming units (CFU) compared to placebo, particularly for total G [-] anaerobes, with no observed resistance in tested bacteria and no surface alteration on implants.
population_specificity: 20 patients who underwent posterior implant-placement surgery (16 completed the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic effects of an in-hospital preparation of 0.25% indomethacin spray (IMS) on anticancer drug-induced oral mucositis (OM) pain.
results_summary: The study found that IMS significantly reduced pain scores at 30 minutes post-administration and improved patients' quality of life with a low risk of systemic adverse effects due to the low dose used.
population_specificity: 20 patients (median age 62.0 years) with OM and numerical rating scale scores of ≥5 undergoing chemotherapy or targeted therapy.
study_duration: Pain relief was assessed at 15, 30, and 60 minutes post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the plaque inhibition efficacy of 0.1% octenidine mouthwash (OCT) compared to placebo over 5 days in the absence of mechanical plaque control.
results_summary: OCT significantly inhibited plaque formation, reduced gingival index and salivary bacterial counts compared to placebo, though it caused slightly higher tooth discoloration and mild side effects like tongue staining and dysgeusia.
population_specificity: 201 healthy adults
effective_dosage: 0.1% octenidine mouthwash, rinsed twice daily for 30 seconds

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Listerine and Biotène mouthwashes in preventing oropharyngeal gonorrhoea among men who have sex with men (MSM).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of oropharyngeal gonorrhoea between the Listerine and Biotène groups, with 7% and 4% infection rates, respectively. The cumulative incidence at 12 weeks also showed no significant difference between the two mouthwashes.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM), either diagnosed with oropharyngeal gonorrhoea in the past 30 days or aged 16-24 years.
effective_dosage: 20 mL, rinsed and gargled for 60 seconds at least once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of commercially available antiseptic mouthwashes (containing chlorhexidine digluconate and octenidine dihydrochloride) against SARS-CoV-2 using the European Standard EN 14476.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwashes achieved a reduction of at least four decimal logarithms (≥4 log) in SARS-CoV-2, meeting the EN 14476 standard for efficacy. The results suggest potential utility in reducing viral transmission via aerosols.
population_specificity: Not specified (commercially available mouthwashes tested in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a new dexamethasone mouthwash formulation for managing stomatitis in patients receiving stomatitis-producing antineoplastic agents.
results_summary: The dexamethasone mouthwash was well tolerated, with no dose reductions or discontinuations due to stomatitis. In patients with existing stomatitis, all achieved significant reduction in severity after using the mouthwash.
population_specificity: Patients receiving everolimus (prophylaxis cohort) and patients with stomatitis induced by high-probability chemotherapy agents (treatment cohort).
study_duration: Until discontinuation of everolimus (prophylaxis cohort) or unspecified for treatment cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of 0.1% curcumin mouthwash versus 0.15% benzydamine mouthwash in delaying or reducing the severity of radiation-induced oral mucositis (RIOM) in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: Curcumin mouthwash significantly delayed the onset of RIOM by 2 weeks compared to benzydamine, with a 50% lower instantaneous risk of onset. Both mouthwashes were equally effective in preventing severe RIOM, though neither completely prevented its occurrence.
population_specificity: 74 head and neck cancer patients scheduled to receive radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 0.1% curcumin mouthwash and 0.15% benzydamine mouthwash (frequency not specified).

study_goal: To assess the effects of oral hygiene care (OHC), including mouthwash, on the incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in critically ill patients receiving mechanical ventilation.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine mouthwash or gel, as part of OHC, probably reduces the incidence of VAP from 26% to about 18% compared to placebo or usual care. No significant differences were found in mortality, duration of mechanical ventilation, or ICU stay, though evidence was low certainty.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients receiving mechanical ventilation for at least 48 hours in intensive care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of oral bacteria in mediating the cardiovascular benefits of dietary nitrate and the impact of chlorhexidine-based mouthwash on nitrate-to-nitrite conversion and blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that using chlorhexidine-based mouthwash reduced nitrate-to-nitrite conversion and was associated with increased blood pressure in normotensive subjects, suggesting oral bacteria play a key role in nitrate's cardiovascular benefits.
population_specificity: Normotensive human subjects and animals (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a grape vinegar and rose water solution versus chlorhexidine mouthwash in treating chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis.
results_summary: Both chlorhexidine mouthwash and the grape vinegar and rose water solution reduced chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis, with similar therapeutic effects between the two treatments.
population_specificity: 60 chemotherapy patients (53 completed the study) with oral mucositis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of clobetasol oral gel 0.05% versus an anti-inflammatory mouthwash in managing symptomatic oral lichen planus (OLP) and assess the risk of side effects.
results_summary: The study compared clobetasol gel and an anti-inflammatory mouthwash for OLP management, evaluating symptoms (pain) and signs (lesions) over three months. Results indicated efficacy, but specific outcomes for the mouthwash were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 40 patients with symptomatic oral lichen planus (20 per treatment group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mouthwash contained calcium hydroxide, hyaluronic acid, umbelliferone, and oligomeric pro-anthocyanidins).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a 14-day course of mouthwash twice daily versus standard antibiotic treatment for curing oropharyngeal gonorrhoea.
results_summary: The mouthwash arm showed a 20% cure rate at Day 14, significantly lower than the 100% cure rate in the standard treatment arm, leading to early trial termination due to high failure rates.
population_specificity: Men with untreated oropharyngeal gonorrhoea.
effective_dosage: Rinsing, gargling, and spraying mouthwash twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an immunologically active saliva substitute (IASS) mouthwash versus a non-immunologically active mouthwash (placebo) on subjective and objective xerostomia measurements in nasopharyngeal cancer survivors.
results_summary: The IASS mouthwash significantly reduced subjective xerostomia scores (SXI) and improved salivary flow (UWS) compared to the placebo, with no harmful side effects reported. The differences between the two treatment arms were statistically significant (p < 0.0001 for both outcomes).
population_specificity: Nasopharyngeal cancer survivors with xerostomia (n=94).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of nitric oxide (NO) and its metabolites (nitrite and nitrate) in metabolic and cardiovascular homeostasis, but the abstract does not specify a direct study goal related to mouthwash.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results specific to mouthwash or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a mouthwash containing antivirals (β-cyclodextrin and Citrox®) versus a placebo on SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva and nasal samples over 7 days.
results_summary: The study measured changes in SARS-CoV-2 viral load in saliva and nasal samples, but the abstract does not specify the magnitude or statistical significance of these changes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-85 with confirmed Covid-19 infection and symptoms present for less than 8 days, excluding regular mouthwash users and high-risk patients.
effective_dosage: Tri-daily mouthwash (specific volume not stated) for 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the antimicrobial uses of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash in dentistry, focusing on its effectiveness and safety for various oral diseases.
results_summary: The study found evidence supporting short-term use of CHX for managing dental plaque, reducing gingivitis symptoms, and minimizing bacterial aerosolization, but noted side effects like tooth staining and rare allergic reactions. Evidence for its effectiveness in treating periodontitis, dental caries, and other conditions was less certain.
population_specificity: General dental patients and practitioners (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical performance and side effects of two 0.2% chlorhexidine mouthwashes—one with and one without an anti-discoloration system—following periodontal surgery.
results_summary: The control mouthwash (without anti-discoloration) significantly reduced plaque and gingival inflammation compared to the test mouthwash, while the test mouthwash caused significantly less staining in gingival and approximal areas. No difference in patient preference was observed.
population_specificity: 38 patients undergoing periodontal flap surgery.

study_goal: To assess the benefits and harms of antimicrobial mouthwashes and nasal sprays for reducing COVID-19 transmission risk during aerosol-generating procedures in healthcare workers and patients without suspected or confirmed infection.
results_summary: No completed studies were found to include in the review, and no ongoing studies addressing the clinical question were identified. The absence of evidence highlights a gap in research on this topic.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers and patients undergoing aerosol-generating procedures without suspected or confirmed COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: To compare the effects of Cystus® tea and sage tea mouthwashes on oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radio(chemo)therapy.
results_summary: Both Cystus® and sage tea mouthwashes showed similar effects on the latency and incidence of mucositis grade 3, with no significant differences between the groups. The tolerability and self-assessment of oral mucosa were also comparable.
population_specificity: 60 head and neck cancer patients undergoing primary or postoperative radio(chemo)therapy.
study_duration: From the start of therapy until mucositis grade 3 occurred (between day 16 and 50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of propolis-based mouthwash compared to chlorhexidine (CHX) in reducing dental plaque and gingival inflammation.
results_summary: Propolis mouthwashes showed good efficacy in reducing plaque and gingivitis, with some studies reporting equal or superior efficacy to CHX, though methodological limitations and small sample sizes weakened the evidence.
population_specificity: 333 subjects across nine clinical trials (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of a mixed chlorhexidine (CHX)/hydrogen peroxide (H) mouthwash on oral health in the absence of oral hygiene practices.
results_summary: The study found that the mixed CHX + H mouthwash was effective in maintaining oral health when oral hygiene practices were absent. The results suggest clinical relevance for its use in such conditions.
population_specificity: 52 subjects in a double-blind, randomized two-group parallel experiment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize oral hygiene practices, including mouthwash use, among Mexican older adults and assess associations with sociodemographic and dental variables.
results_summary: The study found that 16.5% of participants used mouthwash as part of their oral hygiene routine, with younger and female respondents more likely to use oral hygiene aids. No specific efficacy outcomes for mouthwash were reported.
population_specificity: Mexican older adults aged ≥60 years in Pachuca, Mexico.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ozonated water mouthwash on early plaque formation and gingival inflammation compared to bidistilled water.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between ozonated water and bidistilled water in preventing plaque formation or reducing gingival inflammation. The test group reported worse taste perception and more adverse effects.
population_specificity: 42 dental students
study_duration: Two experimental periods of 96 hours each, with a 10-day washout

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of honey mouthwash 12.5% and chlorhexidine solution 0.2% in reducing oropharyngeal bacterial colonization in mechanically-ventilated patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in oropharyngeal bacterial colonization between the two mouthwashes. Honey mouthwash 12.5% inhibited Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth by the fourth day, but neither solution reduced overall colonization.
population_specificity: Mechanically-ventilated patients in internal and trauma Intensive Care Units.
effective_dosage: Honey mouthwash 12.5% and chlorhexidine solution 0.2%, applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the possible relationship between the use of mouthwashes containing alcohol and the development of oral and pharyngeal cancers through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence, with 8 case-control studies showing a statistically significant link between alcohol-containing mouthwash and oral cancer, while 3 case-control studies and 3 clinical trials observed no significant evidence or noted potential risks due to alcohol's genotoxicity. The meta-analysis did not provide conclusive evidence to support a definitive relationship.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of honey mouthwash (12.5%) and chlorhexidine solution (0.2%) in reducing oropharyngeal bacterial colonization in mechanically-ventilated patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in oropharyngeal bacterial colonization between the two mouthwashes at any time point. Honey mouthwash inhibited Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth by the fourth day, but neither solution reduced overall bacterial colonization.
population_specificity: Mechanically-ventilated patients in internal and trauma Intensive Care Units.
effective_dosage: Honey mouthwash 12.5% and chlorhexidine 0.2%, applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and pharmacological mechanisms of curcumin in managing periodontitis compared to conventional treatments like chlorhexidine.
results_summary: Studies showed curcumin has equivalent or higher efficacy than chlorhexidine in managing periodontitis, with demonstrated antioxidant, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic properties. The abstract highlights curcumin's potential as a safe and effective herbal alternative for periodontal disease management.
population_specificity: Adults with periodontal disease (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of triphala mouthwash (TRP-MW) with chlorhexidine mouthwash (CHX-MW) in treating plaque-induced gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found that TRP-MW was significantly effective in improving gingival inflammatory parameters, with equal clinical efficacy to CHX-MW, and was noted as a cost-effective alternative with limited side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with plaque-induced gingivitis (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether ketamine mouthwash could significantly reduce severe oral mucositis pain in children undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Ketamine mouthwash did not significantly reduce pain compared to placebo, nor did it decrease the need for rescue pain medications. No significant adverse events were observed.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-18 years with severe oral mucositis due to chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 4 mg/mL solution, single dose of 1 mg/kg.
study_duration: Single administration with pain assessments up to 240 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the antimicrobial efficacy of green tea, its extract EGCG, chlorhexidine, and distilled water as mouthwashes in reducing cariogenic microorganisms in children.
results_summary: EGCG and green tea mouthwashes significantly reduced mutans streptococci and lactobacilli levels, with EGCG showing higher efficacy than green tea but less than chlorhexidine. Both EGCG and green tea were effective alternatives to chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: 47 children aged 5-12 years at high caries risk and prevalence.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants rinsed with one of the substances for one minute).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a mouthwash containing Teucrium polium herb on reducing Streptococcus mutans in human saliva.
results_summary: The study found that the mouthwash with Teucrium polium significantly reduced S. mutans colonies in saliva (P = 0.002), while the control mouthwash showed no significant effect. The results were consistent across both phases of the crossover trial.
population_specificity: 22 dental student volunteers
study_duration: Two phases with a three-week washout period (total duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an herbal mouthwash preparation from Plantago ovata hydrocolloid could prevent and treat oral mucositis in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The herbal mouthwash significantly reduced mucositis severity, pain, and xerostomia while improving quality of life compared to placebo. The oral care protocol alone also showed significant benefits in reducing mucositis.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy with adriamycin.
effective_dosage: 500 mg of P. ovata husk in 30 mL water plus three drops of vinegar per dose, used three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe antiseptic practices, including mouthwash use, in dental implant surgery and assess their impact on plaque control and healing.
results_summary: Antiseptic mouthwashes were prescribed to 45.6-86.5% of patients post-surgery, and plaque accumulation was low (mean Silness-Löe index 0.7-0.8), suggesting effectiveness in reducing bacterial plaque. However, the study did not isolate mouthwash effects from other antiseptic interventions like gels or antibiotics.
population_specificity: 911 adult patients receiving dental implants across 4 European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antiplaque, antigingivitis efficacy, side effects, and user perceptions of three commercially available mouthwashes (chlorhexidine, hyaluronic acid, and antioxidant).
results_summary: All mouthwashes significantly reduced plaque and bleeding scores, with chlorhexidine being most effective for plaque reduction. Hyaluronic acid was preferred by participants despite similar efficacy in reducing bleeding. Teeth staining occurred with all interventions.
population_specificity: 75 dental students with biofilm-induced gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a dexamethasone-based elixir mouthwash for preventing chemotherapy-induced stomatitis in patients with early breast cancer.
results_summary: The study compared the incidence, severity, and duration of stomatitis between patients using the dexamethasone-based mouthwash and those receiving standard oral care, with the primary endpoint being the difference in stomatitis incidence. Secondary endpoints included stomatitis severity, duration, chemotherapy completion rate, and adverse events.
population_specificity: Women with early breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 10 mL of 0.1 mg/mL dexamethasone-based elixir, swished for 2 minutes and spit, four times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the plaque inhibitory and anti-inflammatory effects of hyaluronan (HA) mouthwash against chlorhexidine (CHX) and distilled water (DW) in a 4-day non-brushing model, while also assessing participant preferences.
results_summary: CHX showed the best plaque inhibition, closely followed by HA, with no significant differences in anti-inflammatory effects between HA and CHX. HA was better tolerated, with participants reporting fewer adverse sensations compared to CHX and DW.
population_specificity: 33 systemically and periodontally healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of simvastatin mouthwash as an adjunct treatment for gingivitis and periodontitis when used alongside scaling and root planning.
results_summary: The study found that 1% simvastatin mouthwash significantly reduced periodontal parameters and inflammatory biomarkers compared to standard treatment alone, with statistically significant results (p<0.001).
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis and periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adjunctive topical antibiotic treatment (including mouthwash) provides better resolution for oral lesions in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) patients compared to supportive care.
results_summary: The study identified palliative treatments like "magic" mouthwash, chlorhexidine 0.12%, and lidocaine 2% gel as commonly used for oral lesions in SJS, but efficacy comparisons were limited to case reports. The case report highlighted an innovative use of dapsone gel 5%, but no direct efficacy data on mouthwash was provided.
population_specificity: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) exhibiting oral manifestations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether professional oral care (POC) could reduce the incidence and severity of everolimus-induced oral mucositis compared to standard oral hygiene practices.
results_summary: POC significantly reduced the incidence of grade 1 and grade 2 oral mucositis compared to the control group (76.5% vs. 89.7% for grade 1, 34.6% vs. 54% for grade 2). POC also led to fewer dose reductions of everolimus due to mucositis (22% vs. 32.2%).
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative advanced or metastatic breast cancer receiving everolimus and exemestane.
effective_dosage: Not specified for mouthwash (control group used 0.9% sodium chloride solution or water for gargling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary oats influence the immune status of the intestinal mucosa in children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a substantial fraction of pediatric celiac disease patients may not tolerate oats, as evidenced by elevated immune-related mRNAs and affected tight junctions. Significant differences were observed for claudin-4 and KLRC3/NKG2E, suggesting immune activation and epithelial stress.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review long-term intervention studies investigating the effects of oats or oat bran on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors.
results_summary: Oats significantly reduced total cholesterol (2-19%) and LDL-cholesterol (4-23%) in hypercholesterolaemic subjects, but showed no significant effects on HDL-cholesterol, TAG concentrations, blood pressure, insulin sensitivity, or inflammation markers.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolaemic subjects (most studies) and general populations (some studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ACC deaminase-producing bacteria could improve the growth of oats in saline soil under various conditions.
results_summary: The study found that PGPB treatments (UW3+UW4 and CMH3) significantly enhanced oat shoot biomass in field tests, with UW3+UW4 tripling and CMH3 doubling shoot biomass compared to untreated plants. These treatments also improved root and shoot growth in greenhouse trials.
population_specificity: Oats grown in saline soil conditions (pouch assays, greenhouse, and field trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether including oats in a gluten-free diet affects gut microflora function and safety in children with coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that children on a gluten-free diet with oats maintained high faecal SCFA levels, unlike those on a standard gluten-free diet. Higher acetic acid, n-butyric acid, and total SCFA concentrations were observed in the oats group, suggesting oats may affect gut microflora and pose a risk for mucosal inflammation in some children.
population_specificity: Children with newly diagnosed coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the optimal serum concentration of digoxin and ouabain for efficacy and safety in heart failure treatment, as well as their effects on the autonomic nervous system.
results_summary: The study found that cardiac glycosides like digoxin and ouabain exhibit biphasic dose-response curves, with low concentrations showing vagomimetic effects and high concentrations showing sympathomimetic effects. Ouabain, in particular, has potential for oral administration and may improve heart failure treatment, warranting further clinical evaluation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general heart failure patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a bioactive compound containing oat bran, soy protein, and flaxseed could improve lipid profiles and control metabolic disorders in HIV/AIDS patients undergoing HAART.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in lipid levels or uricemia after 3 months of consuming the formulation. The results suggest the compound, at the given dosage, did not effectively improve metabolic outcomes in the study group.
population_specificity: HIV/AIDS patients undergoing HAART (31 participants included in final analysis).
effective_dosage: 20g of oat bran daily (as part of a 40g formulation containing flaxseed and soy protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of plant growth-promoting bacteria (PGPR) and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) on oat plants' ability to remediate petroleum-contaminated saline-alkali soil.
results_summary: Petroleum inhibited oat growth, but inoculation with PGPR and AMF increased dry weight and stem height, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and proline), and enhanced soil enzyme activity. The combination also improved petroleum hydrocarbon degradation, reaching up to 49.73% in moderately contaminated soil.
population_specificity: Oat plants (Avena sativa) grown in saline-alkali soil contaminated with petroleum.
effective_dosage: Soil contamination levels of 5 and 10 g/kg petroleum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess compliance with a gluten-free diet (GFD) among celiac children and determine the prevalence and tolerance of oats in their diet.
results_summary: Most celiac children (89.4%) included oats in their diet for an average of 3.4 years, with 81.9% consuming purified oats. Only 5.9% of those who avoided oats did so due to symptoms, and most reported no adverse effects from long-term oat consumption.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency: 45.3% consumed oats less than once a week)
study_duration: Mean time on GFD was 6.9 years; mean oat consumption duration was 3.4 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature to determine whether oats are safe for people with coeliac disease to consume.
results_summary: The study found that oats may be less harmful than previously thought for people with coeliac disease, but safety could vary by oat strain. Contamination with gluten from other cereals and unclear oat strains in past studies complicate conclusions.
population_specificity: People with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purified oats in a gluten-free diet affect intestinal permeability and gastrointestinal symptoms in children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gastrointestinal symptoms (GSRS score) or intestinal permeability (L/M ratio) between children consuming oats or placebo, suggesting oats do not negatively impact these measures in celiac patients.
population_specificity: Italian children with celiac disease.
study_duration: 15 months (6 months per diet phase with a 3-month standard GFD interval).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the first use and successful application of the OAT System for treating partial aseptic necrosis of a metacarpal head.
results_summary: The study showed the successful use of the OAT System for treating partial aseptic necrosis in a metacarpal head, indicating its potential effectiveness for this application.
population_specificity: Patients with partial aseptic necrosis of a metacarpal head.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the preferred method of performing allograft osteochondral articular transplant (OAT) for treating larger chondral injuries and the perioperative management considerations.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of OAT, only stating that it discusses the preferred surgical method and perioperative considerations.
population_specificity: Patients with larger chondral injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the pancreatic lipase inhibitory effects of different subfractions from ethanol extracts of nonfermented and fungi-fermented oats and to analyze the interactions of primary phenolic acids in the EA subfractions.
results_summary: The EA subfraction showed the highest inhibitory effect on pancreatic lipase activity, with fungi-fermented oats demonstrating more effective inhibition than nonfermented oats. A positive correlation between total phenolics content and inhibitory activity was found, and synergistic effects were observed among phenolic acids.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hydrothermal treatment on the carbohydrate and lignin composition of oats and other cereal and oilseed straws.
results_summary: The study found that hydrothermal treatment enriched the glucan content of oats and extracted more than 90% of the xylan and nearly 50% of the lignin. Cereal crops, including oats, yielded residues richer in glucan and lower in lignin compared to oilseed crops.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on crop straws, not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved hydrothermal treatment, not dosage administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current knowledge of human organic anion and cation drug uptake transporters, including OATs, within the SLCO and SLC22A superfamilies.
results_summary: The study found that OATs, along with OATPs and OCTs, play a significant role in drug absorption, distribution, and elimination, transporting various endogenous and exogenous substrates, including drugs. Polymorphisms in these transporters can affect drug pharmacokinetics, highlighting their importance in pharmacological therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on transporter families in general, not a specific human population).
study_duration: Not applicable (review article, not an intervention study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the roles, tissue distribution, and interactions of organic anion transporters (OAT1-10) and URAT1, particularly their involvement in drug transport and urate absorption.
results_summary: The study found that OAT1 and OAT3 facilitate drug uptake in renal cells, OAT4 and URAT1 are involved in drug excretion and urate absorption, and OAT10 interacts with nicotinate and drugs. Extrarenal locations of OATs include the blood-brain barrier, placenta, nasal epithelium, and liver.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on molecular and cellular mechanisms).
interactions: Mentioned interactions with drugs and endogenous compounds, including uricosuric drugs and estrone sulfate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in phenolic compounds and antioxidant activity in oats during steeping and germination.
results_summary: Germination increased free and total phenolics while decreasing bound phenolics. Antioxidant activity correlated significantly with phenolic content, increasing during steeping and germination. Phenolic acids and avenanthramides showed varying trends, with some increasing and others decreasing or remaining stable.
population_specificity: Naked oat samples (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Duration of steeping and germination not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for detecting T-2 and HT-2 toxins produced by Fusarium langsethiae in oat-based media.
results_summary: The study found that extraction with methanol:water (80:20, v/v) for 90 minutes, drying with N(2), and LC-DAD analysis was the most effective method for detecting T-2 and HT-2 toxins in oat-based media, with detection levels of 0.459 and 0.508 mg/kg of agar, respectively. The method was successfully applied to analyze toxin production in 6 F. langsethiae strains.
population_specificity: Fusarium langsethiae strains from northern Europe grown on oat-based media.
effective_dosage: Not specified (toxin stock solutions added to media).
study_duration: Extraction times tested were 30, 60, or 90 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high amounts of kilned and unkilned oats on nutrient intakes in celiac patients in remission.
results_summary: The study found that both kilned and unkilned oats increased intakes of certain nutrients (vitamin B1, magnesium, and zinc) in celiac patients. The type of oats did not affect consumption amounts, and oats improved the nutritional value of a gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: 13 men and 18 women with celiac disease in remission.
study_duration: 6 months per treatment group (total 12 months with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the occurrence and behavior of T-2 and HT-2 toxins in oats during agricultural production, cleaning, and food processing.
results_summary: The study found that T-2/HT-2 toxin levels in oats varied widely (9–623 µg/kg), with de-hulling reducing levels by over 90%, but baking and boiling showed minimal reduction. Cultivars Pergamon and Ivory had the lowest toxin concentrations in 80% of samples.
population_specificity: Four oat cultivars (Aragon, Dominik, Ivory, Pergamon) from ten agricultural sites in Germany.
effective_dosage: Not specified (toxin levels measured, not administered).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the safety of pure oats for individuals with celiac disease, addressing historical debate and limitations in the scientific literature.
results_summary: The majority of evidence suggests that most people with celiac disease can tolerate moderate amounts of pure oats, though a small subset may be intolerant. Oats provide nutritional benefits like high fiber and vitamin B, but long-term assessments by health professionals are recommended.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether providing GPs with open access to hysterosalpingography (HSG) would reduce the time for infertile couples to receive a diagnosis and management plan compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found that open access to HSG did not significantly reduce the time to diagnosis and management plan for infertile couples. There was no meaningful difference in outcomes between intervention and control practices.
population_specificity: Infertile couples presenting to general practices in north-east England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oats induce toxic effects in children with coeliac disease by examining mucosal autoantibody deposits and serum antibodies over a 2-year period.
results_summary: The study found that oats did not induce TG2 autoantibody production at the mucosal level in children with coeliac disease, and the intensity of mucosal deposits remained stable during oat consumption. Serum autoantibody levels and villous morphology correlated well with mucosal deposits, supporting oats' safety in this population.
population_specificity: Children with coeliac disease in remission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Mega-OATS procedure in restoring knee joint loading tolerance and delaying degenerative arthrosis in patients with large osteochondral defects.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in the Lysholm Score from 62 preoperatively to 85 at 12 months and 81 at 55 months postoperatively, with high subjective satisfaction in over 90% of patients. MRI results indicated good graft viability and intact meniscus.
population_specificity: Patients with extensive osteochondral defects in the femoral condyle, excluding those with tricompartmental arthrosis, chronic arthritis, or age >55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cellular-level production of oat phytoalexins (avenanthramides) in response to elicitor treatment and their association with the hypersensitive response (HR).
results_summary: The study found that avenanthramides production occurs in three distinct cell phases, with biosynthesis localized to chloroplasts and linked to the hypersensitive response leading to cell death. Individual mesophyll cells exhibited varying susceptibility to elicitor treatment.
population_specificity: Mesophyll cells of oat (Avena sativa L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term safety and immunological impact of oats in the gluten-free diets of adult coeliac patients.
results_summary: The study found no differences in mucosal immune cell densities between oat-consuming and control groups, indicating oats did not stimulate adverse immunological responses in coeliac patients over 5 years.
population_specificity: Adult coeliac patients (n=42, with 12 consuming oats long-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and tolerability of large amounts of unkilned oats versus kilned oats in adult coeliac patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in duodenal biopsies, endomysial antibody levels, or patient well-being, indicating that both unkilned and kilned oats were well tolerated. Compliance with the diet remained stable, suggesting oats are safe for coeliac patients.
population_specificity: Adult coeliac patients in remission (13 men and 19 women).
study_duration: 1 year (with treatment groups switching after 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combination of patellofemoral arthroplasty (PFA) and autologous osteochondral transplantation for treating isolated patellofemoral osteoarthritis and delaying the need for total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found that combining PFA with autologous osteochondral transplantation delayed the need for TKA in five out of six knees over a mean follow-up period of 3.8 years. Only one patient required TKA during the study period.
population_specificity: Five patients (six knees) with isolated patellofemoral osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pure, uncontaminated oats are safe for individuals with celiac disease and dermatitis herpetiformis when consumed in limited quantities.
results_summary: The study found that pure oats, when uncontaminated with gluten-containing grains and consumed in limited quantities (up to 70 g/day for adults and 25 g/day for children), are safe for most individuals with celiac disease. These oats must meet strict gluten-free standards set by Canadian regulatory agencies.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease and dermatitis herpetiformis.
effective_dosage: Adults: up to 70 g (1/2 to 3/4 cup) per day; Children: up to 25 g (1/4 cup) per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of compatible arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungal communities on the growth and phosphorus content of sea oats planted at two coastal sites.
results_summary: Sea oats planted at the Atlantic coast site showed greater root colonization, shoot dry mass, and shoot-P content compared to those at the Gulf coast site. Local AM fungal communities enhanced growth and phosphorus uptake, with site-specific responses observed between host and fungal ecotypes.
population_specificity: Sea oats (Uniola paniculata L.) from Atlantic (Anastasia State Recreation Area) and Gulf coast (St. George Island State Park) populations.
study_duration: 2 years (field study after 8 weeks of greenhouse growth)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which avenanthramide-c (Avn-c) from oats inhibits vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation, focusing on its effects on the cell cycle.
results_summary: Avn-c arrested the cell cycle in G1 phase by decreasing pRb phosphorylation, reducing cyclin D1 expression, and increasing p21cip1 expression. This effect was linked to increased p53 protein stability, suggesting a potential role in preventing atherosclerosis.
population_specificity: Rat embryonic aortic smooth muscle cell line A10.

study_goal: To study the long-term safety of oats in children with coeliac disease and determine if oats cause intestinal deterioration or immune activation.
results_summary: Oats had no detrimental effect on intestinal histology or serology in children with coeliac disease over 2 years, and all patients remained in remission even after extended follow-up. Gluten challenge caused relapse, but recovery was achieved with an oat-containing gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: Children with coeliac disease (32 participants, including those in remission and newly diagnosed).
study_duration: 2-year trial with follow-up extended up to 7 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether avenanthramide-2c, a polyphenol found in oats, inhibits vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation and enhances nitric oxide production in vascular cells.
results_summary: Avenanthramide-2c significantly inhibited serum-induced SMC proliferation and dose-dependently increased NO production in both SMC and HAEC, with a nine-fold increase in HAEC at 120 microM. These effects were linked to upregulation of endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) mRNA expression.
population_specificity: Rat SMC line (A10) and human aortic endothelial cells (HAEC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolism of avenanthramides in oat leaves in response to pathogen infection or elicitor treatment.
results_summary: The study found that avenanthramides, particularly avenanthramide B, are actively biosynthesized and metabolized in oat leaves, with metabolism enhanced by elicitor treatment and involving inducible isoperoxidases. Radiolabeled avenanthramide B was incorporated into the cell wall fraction and released by alkaline treatment.
population_specificity: Oat leaf segments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cooked waxy barley (containing β-glucan) on upper respiratory tract symptoms and mood status in healthy adults.
results_summary: Participants receiving cooked waxy barley reported a reduction in cumulative days of sneezing, suggesting potential benefits for upper respiratory symptoms. The abstract does not provide full details on mood status or statistical significance.
population_specificity: 27 healthy Japanese adults
effective_dosage: 100 g of cooked waxy barley daily (containing 1.8 g of β-glucan)

study_goal: To determine the effects of oat ingestion on endothelial function in overweight, dyslipidemic adults, both acutely and after sustained treatment.
results_summary: Oats non-significantly increased flow-mediated vasodilation (FMD) with both acute and sustained treatment, though the effect was not statistically significant in either phase alone. When acute and sustained effects were pooled, oat treatment significantly augmented FMD.
population_specificity: Overweight, dyslipidemic adults (16 males ≥ age 35; 14 postmenopausal females).
study_duration: Single acute dose and 6 weeks of sustained treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the induction of defense compounds in oats in response to nematode invasion and methyl jasmonate treatment, and assess their protective effects against cereal nematodes.
results_summary: The study found that flavone-C-glycosides, particularly O-methyl-apigenin-C-deoxyhexoside-O-hexoside, were induced by nematode invasion and methyl jasmonate, impairing nematode invasion and development. Methyl jasmonate treatment reduced nematode invasion and increased plant mass, compensating for nematode damage.
population_specificity: Oats cv. Quoll seedlings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the MEGA-OATS technique using osteochondral allografts for treating large osteochondral defects in the knee of young patients.
results_summary: The study found that the MEGA-OATS technique improved patients' Lysholm knee scores from 37.8 to 73.8 and Tegner activity scores from 2 to 4, with four out of five patients returning to work and three resuming sporting activities. The technique effectively addressed sizable defects and subchondral bone loss while reconstructing femoral condyle curvature.
population_specificity: Young patients (aged 22-41) with large osteochondral defects in the knee.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 30 to 36 months (mean: 32.8 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic supplementation with oat-derived avenanthramides (AVA) could reduce inflammatory and immunological markers in response to acute downhill running in humans.
results_summary: Oat AVA supplementation reduced inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and cell adhesion molecules post-exercise, with notable decreases in neutrophil respiratory burst, G-CSF, and sVCAM-1 levels, and alleviated muscle soreness at later time points.
population_specificity: 11 male and 13 female subjects.
effective_dosage: 206 mg/kg AVA daily via two cookies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Caricol®-Gastro, a combination of papaya and oats, as an add-on therapy for reducing symptoms in patients with chronic gastritis.
results_summary: The study found that both the Caricol®-Gastro and placebo groups showed symptom improvement, but the Caricol®-Gastro group had significantly greater pain reduction (p=0.048), suggesting a beneficial effect from the supplement's anti-inflammatory and epithelial integrity properties.
population_specificity: 60 patients with endoscopically confirmed mild chronic gastritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation of avenanthramides (AVA) in oats could enhance antioxidant protection and reduce inflammation in humans following eccentric exercise.
results_summary: AVA supplementation blunted neutrophil respiratory burst, lowered interleukin-6 and NFκB activity post-exercise, and increased antioxidant capacity, while control group effects were less pronounced. Both groups showed increased total antioxidant activity, but only the AVA group exhibited improved glutathione-related markers.
population_specificity: Young women aged 18-30 years (N = 16).
effective_dosage: 9.2 mg AVA daily (via oat flour cookies).
